conclusion: Analyze forces to find mass ratio of ball A to ball C.
Ball A is hanging vertically, ball B is in equilibrium, ball C is hanging vertically.
Identify forces on each ball: Ball A has weight and tension T1, Ball B has tensions T1 and T2 and weight, Ball C has weight and tension T2.
For ball B to have no pressure on the bowl wall, horizontal components of tensions must balance.
Vertical components of tensions and weight of ball B must balance: T1 cos(30°) + T2 cos(30°) = mB g.
Horizontal components of tensions must balance: T1 sin(30°) = T2 sin(30°).
Simplify horizontal force equation: T1 = T2.
Substitute T1 = T2 into vertical force equation: 2 T1 cos(30°) = mB g.
Solve for T1: T1 = mB g / √3.
Relate tensions to masses: T1 = mA g and T2 = mC g.
Since T1 = T2, mA g = mC g, thus mA = mC.
Mass ratio of ball A to ball C is 1:1.
